docs.lead_paragraph: The partisan fiscal showdown that is set to unfold in the weeks between Election Day and Inauguration Day is expected to set the tone for the next administration, no matter who wins.

headline.seo: Budget Crisis Likely to Define Obama or Romney Term
headline.main: Debt Impasse Shadows Race for Presidency
headline.print_headline: Debt Impasse Shadows Race For Presidency

docs.abstract: Political Memo; partisan fiscal showdown that is set to unfold in the weeks between Election Day and Inauguration Day is expected to set the tone for the next administration, no matter who wins the presidency; without agreement of some kind, more than $700 billion in automatic tax increases and spending cuts will occur on Dec 31.
docs.snippet: The partisan fiscal showdown that is set to unfold in the weeks between Election Day and Inauguration Day is expected to set the tone for the next administration, no matter who wins.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s claim that he can lower tax rates by 20 percent and pay for it by ending deductions has run into a wall.

headline.seo: Mitt Romney Needs a Working Calculator
headline.main: Mr. Romney Needs a Working Calculator
headline.print_headline: Mr. Romney Needs a Working Calculator

docs.abstract: Editorial notes that a new analysis by the bipartisan Joint Committee on Taxation has found that Mitt Romney's proposed tax plan could not possibly reduce tax rates by 20 percent merely by ending loopholes and deductions; holds that the proposal is simply another rhapsody based on old Republican themes that something can be had for nothing.
docs.snippet: Mitt Romney’s claim that he can lower tax rates by 20 percent and pay for it by ending deductions has run into a wall.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers react to a column by Nicholas D. Kristof about a sick friend without health insurance.

headline.main: Paying the Price of Being Uninsured
headline.print_headline: Paying the Price of Being Uninsured

docs.snippet: Readers react to a column by Nicholas D. Kristof about a sick friend without health insurance.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.abstract: Public support for effective contraception choices makes good economic sense, by a cost-benefit analysis of the sort Republicans otherwise embrace.
docs.snippet: Public support for effective contraception choices makes good economic sense, by a cost-benefit analysis of the sort Republicans otherwise embrace.

keywords.value: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite what Mitt Romney says, the lack of health insurance does kill people.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column maintains that Mitt Romney's remark that nobody in America dies because they lack health insurance is not only inaccurate but also demonstrates how he has no idea what life is like for those less fortunate; argues that Romney's health care proposals, which involve taking insurance away from some 45 million Americans, will only lead to more people who cannot afford crucial care.
docs.snippet: Despite what Mitt Romney says, the lack of health insurance does kill people.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Excluding a drug that’s no better, and twice as expensive, isn’t rationing — it’s rational.

headline.seo: A Hospital Says ‘No’ to an $11,000-a-Month Cancer Drug

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Peter B Bach, Leonard B Saltz and Robert E Wittes, doctors at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, explains the hospital's decision not to use new cancer drug Zaltrap, which has proved to be no more effective but is more than twice as expensive; contends that this is one example of how the medical community needs to consider financial costs of treatments for patients alongside their benefits.
docs.snippet: Excluding a drug that’s no better, and twice as expensive, isn’t rationing — it’s rational.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By PETER B. BACH, LEONARD B. SALTZ and ROBERT E. WITTES

docs.lead_paragraph: Regulators are noting new abuses tied to reverse mortgages, which let people 62 and older borrow money against the value of their homes and not pay it back until they move out or die.

headline.seo: Reverse Mortgages Costing Some Older Americans Their Homes
headline.main: A Risky Lifeline for the Elderly Is Costing Some Their Homes
headline.print_headline: Abuse Growing In Loan Option For the Elderly

docs.abstract: Federal and state regulators report increasing abuse tied to reverse mortgages, which are designed to allow seniors to stay in their homes; under scrutiny are smaller mortgage brokers, including former subprime lenders, that flooded the market after the recent exit of big banks; Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is working on rules that could mean better disclosure for consumers and stricter supervision of such lenders.
docs.snippet: Regulators are noting new abuses tied to reverse mortgages, which let people 62 and older borrow money against the value of their homes and not pay it back until they move out or die.
